title: SQLDELETEStatement

metadata.description: Learn about SQLDELETEStatement with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
The SQL DELETE Statement
The
DELETE
statement is used to delete existing records in a table.
DELETE Syntax
DELETE FROM
table_name
WHERE
condition
;
Note:
Be careful when deleting records in a table! Notice the
WHERE
clause in the
DELETE
statement.
The
WHERE
clause specifies which record(s) should be deleted. If 
you omit the
WHERE
clause, all records in the table will be deleted!
Demo Database
Below is a selection from the
Customers
table used in the examples:

SQL DELETE Example
The following SQL statement deletes the customer "Alfreds Futterkiste" from 
the "Customers" table:
Example
DELETE FROM Customers
 WHERE CustomerName='Alfreds Futterkiste';
The "Customers" table will now look like this:

CustomerName
ContactName

Delete All Records
It is possible to delete all rows in a table without deleting the table. This 
means that the table structure, attributes, and indexes will be intact:
DELETE FROM
table_name
;
The following SQL statement deletes all rows in the "Customers" table, without deleting the table:
Example
DELETE FROM Customers;
Delete a Table
To delete the table completely, use the
DROP TABLE
statement:
Example
Remove the Customers table:
DROP TABLE Customers;

★
+1

content_sections.code:
DELETE FROM Customers
 WHERE CustomerName='Alfreds Futterkiste';

summary: This tutorial covers SQLDELETEStatement concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use SQLDELETEStatement effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of SQLDELETEStatement and how to apply it in your projects.
